steps.title: You can take 200- or 300-milligram tablets of acetaminophen or ibuprofen.
steps.content: You can take 200- or 300-milligram tablets of acetaminophen or ibuprofen. Only take 1 dose at a time and wait about 30 minutes to feel relief. If you still have pain 4–6 hours later, it’s okay for you to take another pain reliever. [1] X Research source Avoid taking more than 4 doses within 24 hours since it may cause liver problems. [2] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Painkillers that contain codeine can cause constipation, so be sure not to use them. [3] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source

steps.title: This ointment can help reduce swelling.
steps.content: This ointment can help reduce swelling. Squeeze a fingertip-sized amount of the ointment onto your finger or a cotton applicator pad. Gently rub the ointment onto your hemorrhoids to start feeling instant relief. Be sure to wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water immediately after you apply the cream so you don’t spread any bacteria. Use your ointment up to 4 times daily for 1 week to see if it shrinks your hemorrhoids. [4] X Research source Wear disposable gloves while applying your ointment if you have them so you stay sanitary. You may also find pads pre-soaked in witch hazel so it’s easier to wipe your hemorrhoids without touching them directly. Witch hazel contains natural anti-inflammatories and antioxidants, which means it will bring down your swelling and reduce your pain. [5] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: The cool water will help soothe your pain so it doesn’t hurt as much.
steps.content: The cool water will help soothe your pain so it doesn’t hurt as much. Use cold water from your bathroom sink to lightly wet your toilet paper right before you wipe. Be careful not to get the toilet paper too wet, or else it will rip or fall apart. [6] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source You can also use baby wipes, but don’t flush them down your toilet since they could clog your pipes. Throw them in a trash can instead and take out your trash every few days to avoid odors. Don’t apply a lot of pressure while you’re wiping since you could cause more irritation.

steps.title: The cold may help ease your discomfort.
steps.content: The cold may help ease your discomfort. Fill a plastic sandwich bag with ice and wrap a towel around it. You can use the ice over your clothes or put the towel directly against your skin. Keep the ice there for up to 15–20 minutes at a time to bring down your swelling and ease your discomfort. [7] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Don’t put the ice directly against your skin or leave it on for longer than 20 minutes since it could damage your nerves. If you place the towel and ice on your skin rather than over your clothes, be sure to wash it after each time you use it.

steps.title: The heat from the water will help reduce your swelling so your hemorrhoids don’t feel as painful.
steps.content: The heat from the water will help reduce your swelling so your hemorrhoids don’t feel as painful. Fill your tub with at least 6–8 inches (15–20 cm) of the warmest water you can tolerate. Sit down in the bath so your hemorrhoids are completely submerged, but don’t put any pressure on them. Keep soaking for 15–20 minutes at a time before getting out and patting yourself dry. You can do this as many times as you want throughout the day. [8] X Research source [[Image:Reduce Hemorrhoid Pain Step 5 Version 5.jpg|center] You can also buy a sitz bath that fits inside your toilet seat so it’s easy to drain and clean. Just fill it with water from your tub before putting it on your toilet. When you’re finished, just pour the water into your toilet and disinfect the sitz bath with an all-purpose cleaner.

steps.title: Epsom salt contains magnesium, which helps reduce redness and swelling.
steps.content: Epsom salt contains magnesium, which helps reduce redness and swelling. Combine 2 tablespoons (30 g) of Epsom salt with 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of glycerin until they’re thoroughly combined. Put the mixture on a gauze applicator pad and place it against your hemorrhoid. Leave the pad in place for 15–20 minutes to help you get rid of your pain. Throw the pad out immediately when you’re finished using it and wash your hands with soap. You can do this once every 4–6 hours to get relief throughout the day. [9] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You can buy glycerin at your local pharmacy.

steps.title: Forcing yourself to poop can make your hemorrhoids feel worse or even cause them.
steps.content: Forcing yourself to poop can make your hemorrhoids feel worse or even cause them. [10] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Lean forward so your elbows are on your knees and keep your spine straight. If you can, use a squatting position so your knees are higher than your hips to make it easier for you to go. Try to go to the bathroom as soon as you feel the urge since it may be more difficult if you wait.

steps.title: Fiber makes it easier to pass a bowel movement.
steps.content: Fiber makes it easier to pass a bowel movement. Avoid foods that have refined sugars since they aren’t as nutritious as complex carbs. Opt for foods like whole-wheat bread and pasta, brown rice, broccoli, peas, apples, and bananas. [11] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Aim to have between 20–40 grams of fiber daily so you don’t get constipated. [12] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source For example, 1 slice of whole-wheat bread has 2 grams of fiber, 1 cup (150 g) of peas has 9 grams, and a medium-sized apple has 4.5 grams. Other foods that contain good sources of fiber include spinach, cauliflower, beans, granola, and almonds.

steps.title: Processed foods don’t contain as many nutrients and are harder to digest.
steps.content: Processed foods don’t contain as many nutrients and are harder to digest. This means that they may put more strain on your body. Try to cut fast food and processed snacks from your diet as much as possible. Instead, opt for a piece of fruit or an organic granola bar to get nutrients and fiber. [13] X Trustworthy Source National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases Health information from the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, a division of the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Bake, grill, or pan-sear your meals so they aren’t as greasy or oily.

steps.title: Water combines with the fiber and waste in your digestive system and helps soften your stool.
steps.content: Water combines with the fiber and waste in your digestive system and helps soften your stool. Aim to have 8 glasses of water during the day that are each around 8 fluid ounces (240 ml) each. [14] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Try incorporating 100% fruit juice, decaf tea, or low-fat milk to help you stay hydrated. However, stay away from soda and other sugary beverages since they can dehydrate and constipate you. [15] X Trustworthy Source National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases Health information from the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, a division of the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Alcohol and caffeine can stress out your body and make your hemorrhoids feel more painful.
steps.content: Alcohol and caffeine can stress out your body and make your hemorrhoids feel more painful. Try to cut out coffee, soda, and any alcohol you drink while you have hemorrhoids so they don’t flare up with pain. Once your hemorrhoids go away, you can reintroduce them back to your diet. [16] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source

steps.title: Exercise makes it easier to pass bowel movements.
steps.content: Exercise makes it easier to pass bowel movements. Set aside time in your schedule where you can get active so your body stays healthy. Try a variety of workouts, such as biking, jogging, swimming, or lifting weights, to exercise your entire body. As you work out, your body will digest food better to get more nutrients, which will make it easier for you to use the bathroom. [17] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Stool softeners make it easier for you to poop.
steps.content: Stool softeners make it easier for you to poop. Choose a stool softener or fiber supplement containing psyllium or methylcellulose to get the best effects. Take 1 dose of the stool softener daily to help prevent constipation and make you feel more comfortable when you’re using the bathroom. Only use stool softeners for up to 7 days. [18] X Trustworthy Source National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases Health information from the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, a division of the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Avoid using stool softeners if you’re pregnant or breastfeeding. [19] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source

steps.title: This can help soothe hemorrhoid pain and constipation.
steps.content: This can help soothe hemorrhoid pain and constipation. Suppositories are laxatives that help soften your stool so you don’t feel as much pain when you use the bathroom. Wet the pointed end of the suppository with cold water or the lubricant provided in the package. Lie on your left side and bring your left leg up to your chest so it makes a 90-degree angle. Slowly push the suppository into your anus as deep as your finger and stay still for about 5 minutes. Slowly pull out your finger and wash your hands thoroughly with soap. [20] X Trustworthy Source National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases Health information from the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, a division of the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Suppositories usually work within 15–60 minutes. Don’t use suppositories if you’re pregnant or breastfeeding. [21] X Research source Avoid taking a rectal suppository by mouth since it will not be effective.

steps.title: A doctor can confirm if hemorrhoids are the problem or not.
steps.content: A doctor can confirm if hemorrhoids are the problem or not. While hemorrhoids often cause pain and discomfort, there may be other causes for your pain, such as anal fissures, infections, constipation, or a fistula . Contact your doctor to let them know about your symptoms and how long you’ve been experiencing them. They may perform a rectal exam to confirm if you have hemorrhoids or not. [22] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Sometimes a blood vessel in your anus can rupture and form a clot, causing severe pain and swelling. You may need medical treatment to deal with this type of hemorrhoid.

steps.title: Your doctor can make sure nothing serious is at play.
steps.content: Your doctor can make sure nothing serious is at play. If you see bright red blood on your toilet paper or in the toilet, make an appointment to get an exam from your doctor. You should also contact your doctor if your stool looks black or has the appearance of coffee grounds. While rectal bleeding is a common symptom of hemorrhoids, it may also signal that you have a more serious condition, such as anal fissures or bowel disease. [23] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source It’s especially important to get rectal bleeding evaluated if you’re over 40 or have other symptoms, such as changes in the color or consistency of your bowel movements since it could potentially be a sign of rectal or colon cancer. Call emergency services or go to the emergency room if you have bleeding that won’t stop and if you feel dizzy or faint.

steps.title: They will check for any serious complications or underlying problems.
steps.content: They will check for any serious complications or underlying problems. If you’ve been using home treatments on your hemorrhoids for 7 days and they haven’t improved, schedule an appointment with your doctor. They can give you a thorough exam before recommending a specific treatment. [24] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source If you get a high fever or your hemorrhoid leaks pus, contact your doctor immediately since you may have a more serious infection.

steps.title: Surgery may be an option if home treatments aren’t working.
steps.content: Surgery may be an option if home treatments aren’t working. They may inject hemorrhoids to shrink them, cauterize them, or remove them completely if they're large. [25] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Some hemorrhoid surgery methods do not require any cutting. Sometimes hemorrhoids can be dealt with using a simple procedure, such as shrinking them with a laser.
